chapter: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question: Question 1: Tidal volume is

options.a: Inspiratory capacity minus inspiratory reserve volume
options.b: Total lung capacity minus residual volume
options.c: Functional residual capacity minus residual volume
options.d: Vital capacity minus expiratory reserve volume

questions.explanation: The tidal volume = inspiratory capacity - inspiratory reserve volume.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question: Question 2: Functional residual capacity is:

options.b: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.explanation:
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume. From the picture given below, (FRC = ERV + RV). Lung Capacities: The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define 
functioning lungs. • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung 
or maximum inspiratory level. • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after 
expiration of a normal breath.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question:
Question 3: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales 
as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. What is his expiratory 
reserve volume (in liters)? 416 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity - Residual Volume In the given spirogram, • Functional Residual Capacity = 3L • Residual Volume = 1L Therefore, 424 
Sold by @itachibot Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity – Residual Volume = 3-1 = 2 Note: The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after the most forceful expiration. The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. 
This capacity is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration The expiratory reserve volume is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful 
expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question:
Question 4: A nurse in the pulmonology clinic administered a test using the following instrument. Which 
of the following parameters cannot be measured?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows spirometry. All of the given parameters can be measured by a spirometer 
except residual volume. Residual volume is measured by: • N2 washout method • Helium-dilution method • Body plethysmography Other parameters which cannot be measured by spirometry are: • Functional residual capacity • Total lung capacity
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question: Question 5: Total lung capacity depends on
questions.explanation:
Total lung capacity depends on the distensibility of lungs (compliance). Determinants of Lung Compliance • Stretchability of the lung tissues, particularly their elastic connective tissue. • Surface tension at the air-water interfaces within the alveoli, which is markedly reduced in the 
alveoli by pulmonary surfactant preventing their collapse. Option b: The Closing Volume is the lung volume above Residual Volume at which airways in the 
lower, dependent parts of the lungs begin to close off because of the lesser transmural pressure in 
these areas.

questions.question: Question 6: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring
questions.explanation:
Anatomical dead space can be measured by the single-breath N2 curve (Fowler's method). • Anatomical dead space is the respiratory system volume exclusive of alveoli. 425 
Sold by @itachibot • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood i.e. wasted ventilation. • Physiological/total dead space is the sum of anatomical and alveolar dead space. • The equation used for the calculation of total/physiological dead space is the Bohr’s equation. End of IV - Residual Volume (RV). Factors affecting dead space: Option B: Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is measured using body plethysmography. Question 9: A patient has a dead space of 150 mL, a functional residual capacity of 3L, tidal volume of 
Œ50 mL, expiratory reserve volume of 1.5 L, a total lung capacity of èL, respiratory rate of 15 
breaths/min. What is the rate of alveolar ventilation?
questions.explanation:
The rate of alveolar ventilation in this patient is 7.5 L/min. Alveolar ventilation per minute is the total volume of new air entering the alveoli and ad™acent gas 
exchange areas each minute. It is equal to the respiratory rate times the amount of new air that 
enters these areas with each breath. Alveolar ventilation=Respiratory rate ˜ (Tidal volume – Physiologic dead space) = 15 ˜ (Œ50-150) = 7500mL/min or 7.5L/min.

questions.question: Question 10: Closing volume of the lung is

options.a: Above residual volume in upper portions of the lungs
options.b: Above the residual volume in dependent portions of the lungs
options.c: Above tidal volume in dependent portions of the lungs
options.d: Above tidal volume in upper portions of the lungs

questions.explanation:
The closing volume (CV) is the lung volume above the residual volume (RV) at which the airways 
in the lower dependent parts of the lung begin to close off because of the lesser transmural 
pressure in these areas. 427 
Sold by @itachibot In young adults, the closing volume is about 10% of the vital capacity (VC). It increases steadily 
with age and is equal to about 40% of the VC. It equals FRC, at about the age of Œ5 years. Diseases of the small airways apparently increase the closing volume • Normal young adult: CV << FRC • At Œ5 years of age: CV=FRC • Small airway disease: CV >>FRC • In case of hyaline membrane disease, FRC is smaller than closing volume.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

Question 12: 419 
Sold by @itachibot Flow volume given below indicates
questions.explanation:
The inspiratory flow-volume curve is truncated in patients with variable extrathoracic 
obstructions. 428 
Sold by @itachibot • During a forced expiration, the cross-sectional area of a variable extrathoracic obstruction 
increases as the pressure inside the airway increases. • The expiratory flow-volume curve is therefore nearly normal or not affected. • However, during a forced inspiration, the pressure inside the upper airway decreases below 
atmospheric pressure, and unless the stability of the upper airway is maintained by reflex 
contraction of the pharyngeal muscles or by other structures, the cross-sectional area of the upper 
airway will decrease. Therefore, the inspiratory flow-volume curve is truncated in patients with 
variable extrathoracic obstructions. • Flow-volume curves are very useful in assessing obstructions of upper airways and the trachea 
(refer figure and flowchart). 429 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following best describes the changes in lung volume and thoracic volume in a 
case of pneumothorax, compared to normal?
questions.explanation:
In pneumothorax, lung volume is decreased and thoracic volume is increased. Both lungs and the chest wall (thoracic cage) are elastic structures. Under normal conditions, the 
elastic tendency of the lungs to collapse is exactly balanced by the elastic tendency of the chest 
wall to expand. In pneumothorax, air is introduced into the pleural space, so the pleural pressure, which is 
normally subatmospheric, becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. The chest wall springs 
outward and the lungs collapse. This increases the thoracic volume and decreases the lung 
volume.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question:
Question 14: A 45-year-old man inhaled as much air as possible and then expired with a maximum effort 
until no more air could be expired. This produced the maximum expiratory flow-volume 
curve shown in the following diagram. What is the forced vital capacity of this man (in liters)? 420 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The forced vital capacity of this man is 4.5 liters. The forced vital capacity (FVC), the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal 
inspiratory effort, is frequently measured clinically as an index of pulmonary function. Forced vital capacity(FVC) = Total lung capacity (TLC) – Residual volume(RV) • In the flow-volume curve, the point of intersection between abscissa and flow-volume curve gives 
the TLC and RV. • From the given flow-volume curve we can note that: • Total Lung Capacity (TLC) = 5.5 L • Residual volume (RV)= 1.0 L • Thus, 430 
Sold by @itachibot • FVC = TLC – RV = 4.5 L
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question:
Question 15: A 71-year-old woman presents with cough and shortness of breath. The physician conducts a 
pulmonary function screening test in his office, and the patient generates the maximum 
expiratory flow–volume curve shown to the right of the normal curve in the diagram below. 
These findings are consistent with which of the following conditions? 421 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This is a case of asbestosis. Asbestosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis. In restrictive 
lung disease, the maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV) curve begins and ends at abnormally 
low lung volumes. Note: In obstructive lung diseases, the airways are narrowed or radial traction of the airways is 
reduced, allowing them to close more easily. The lung volumes in these cases are higher than 
normal.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question:
Question 16: The maximum expiratory flow-volume (MEFV) curves shown in the figure below were 
obtained from a healthy man (purple curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath 
(green curve). What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The green curve in the above image and the case scenario denotes that the diagnosis is likely to be 
emphysema. Maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV): When a person expires with great force, the expiratory 
airflow reaches a maximum flow beyond which the flow cannot be increased anymore, even with 
greatly increased additional force. In obstructive airway disease like Emphysema, it is usually much more difficult to expire than to 
inspire because the closing tendency of the airways is greatly increased by the extra positive 
pressure during expiration. Due to the obstruction of the airways and because they collapse more 
easily than normal airways, the maximum expiratory flow rate is greatly reduced (But, total lung 
capacity and residual volume is increased) which is shown in the green curve below. Other options given above will cause constricted lungs where the lungs cannot expand to a normal 
maximum volume. Hence, even with the greatest possible expiratory effort, the maximum 431 
Sold by @itachibot expiratory flow rate will be reduced. (Note: here both the total lung capacity and the residual 
volume are reduced), which is shown as the blue curve in the graph below. Following graph shows the MEFV of restrictive and obstructive lung diseases.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following increases in COPD?
questions.explanation:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or 
normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct. • In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more 
than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases. • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema. • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive 
expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased. Lung Capacities: The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define 
functioning lungs. • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung 
or maximum inspiratory level. • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after 
expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + 
residual volume.
questions.chapter_heading: Lung Volumes and Lung Function Tests

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following factors is most likely to stimulate ventilation after strenuous exercise?
questions.explanation:
432 
Sold by @itachibot The stimulus to ventilation after strenuous exercise is increased mean arterial H+. The respiratory rate after exercise does not reach a basal level until the O2 debt is repaid. The 
stimulus for ventilation is increased mean arterial H+ due to an increase in blood lactic acid 
levels. Most of the lactic acid is converted to glycogen and some amount is converted to CO2 and 
H2O. 433 
Sold by @itachibot Respiratory Adaptations in Hypoxia, Anemia and with Pressure Changes
